bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to [Blanton P. Seward], December 15, 1931

div1.p: Laura Carter sends Seward a copy of Frost's notes on Henry Rose Carter. [not enclosed] She describes her father's opinions of Strobel's, Nott's and Bell's yellow fever research and encloses a list of Carter's yellow fever articles.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to [Blanton P. Seward], December 15, 1931
div1.opener:
Carbon letter to
Dr. Blanton P. Seward.
Lewis-Gale Hospital
Roansho, Va.
12/15/31
Re Frost's Notes on Falker.
div1.p: I shall be grateful for itstheir return as soon as you have finished with itthem.

Father's first three articles on the incubation of yellow
fever. I deeply regret that I have no copies that I can send you. My
brother, Dr. Henry Rose Carter, Jr., says, however, that by sending a
minimal sum (less than a dollar) to the A. M. A. in Chicago, they will
send any member from their files, extending far beyond the time
when these articles were written. Also, they have a large and varied
collection of medical journals, so I hope that you will have no trouble.
I enclose exact names of the articles and journals in which they were
published. "A note on the interval' etc. was the one determining the di-
rection of Reed's experiments, published, N. O. Med. &. Surg. Jour. May 1900

Father though extremely well of the work of Strobel and had made a note
to include an appreciation of it in his book. He died before he could do
this, however. In a marginal note (in Father's handwriting) I find: "It was
a question of words only & the dispute ended when Strobel of Charleston, S. C.
(about 1840) substituted the word “transmissible” for “contagious.” We now say
“communicable.” This note on p. 78 of “William Crawford Gorgas.” Doubleday
Page & Co. (1924) by Marie D. Gorgas and Burton Hendrick.

Re Nott: In The Practice of Medicine in the Tropics, Oxford Press, Lon-
don, v. ii, p. 1233: “Beauperthuy and Nott, the former especially, are
frequently mentioned as having formulated the same doctrine as Finlay and
before him. Beauperthuy taught that a mosquito by biting a well man pro-
duced the disease, the insect getting the infection (or poison?) from the
‘putrid’ mud and slime of brackish marshes. To him yellow fever was an
intoxication; the source of infection being the ‘putrid’ marsh. Nott did
not teach conveyance at all. He thought a ‘minute insect’, living on or
near the ground, entered the body of a man and was itself the cause of
yellow fever. Whether the progress of this ‘insect’ was by growth, like
mould, as Faget thought, or by mechanical progression (legs or wings) is
not stated. His idea is rather the forerunner of the microbean origin
of disease than of metaxeny. Neither Beauperthuy nor Nott, ingenious as
were their theories, are rivals of Finlay in the promulgation of the doc-
trine of conveyance of yellow fever from the sick to the well by the mos-
quito.”

I have no clear recollection of Father's evaluation of the work of
Agrippa Nelson Bell. This is not strange, as our work, after Father's
return from Peru, when he began his History of Yellow Fever, was along
very definite lines (as you will see when you read the book) and Bell would
have been mentioned in a much later. Section than that which terminates
the present book.

Wishing you all manner of success in your paper and looking forward
much to seeing it when it appears, I remain
